What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1894
Where did you set up housekeeping? Mat. father's homestead, Grouse Hill
Have you been living there before that? Yes, 6 days (1927)
For how many people did you prepare meals? 3 (mother & my father)
How far was it to your nearest store? About 1 mile
How often would a visit be made to the store? Almost every day
What groceries did you usually buy in those earliest years? Dried apples, flour, beans, tea, flour, rolled oats, sugar, brown sugar.

1. INTRODUCTORY QUESTIONS

What year did you start housekeeping in Western Canada? 1894

Where did you set up housekeeping? My father's farmstead near Fall River.

How many people did you live with before that? 3 (my mother, my father, 6 months old).

For how many years did you live there? About 2 weeks.

How far was it to your nearest store? About 1 mile.

How often could a visit be made to the store? Once a month.

What groceries did you usually buy in those weeks? Dried apples, flour, sugar, brown sugar, tea, flour, rolled oats, sugar, brown sugar.

Poveshell's Cream Syrup.

17. Give a typical day's menu (breakfast, dinner and supper) for the earliest winter season. Remember, give the year and list the members of the family with their ages at the time. State the approximate month, e.g., winter or summer.

Breakfast: porridge + toast or bread & butter, honey or syrup
Dinner: dinner, summer 1895 was taken to camp some place, family quarter
Supper: dinner, summer 1895: pan ca. has 4 cupsful, winter cooked dried
summer: dinner, summer 1895: pan ca. has 4 cupsful, winter cooked dried
apple pie, a fresh apple, coffee
old couple guests 60 years old, son 18 daughters 16
my father 3 brothers 18, 16, 10, only 14 years.

18. What year did you serve your first Christmas dinner in Western Canada?

Give the menu. List those present and give their approximate ages at the time.

1894: turkey, potatoes, bread & butter, cheese
apple pie, a fresh apple, coffee
old couple guests 60 years old, son 18 daughters 16
my father 3 brothers 18, 16, 10, only 14 years.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally produced foods? Give details.

1895 we had no vegetables but family quarter grew
corn on some abandoned farm 1/2 mile away
for a while rabbit meat, frogs, wheat bread,
later found a neighbor where we got butter 10¢ lb.
some potatoes grown in Qu'Appelle valley.

19. Were you ever reduced to almost starvation level living on one or two locally
   produced foods? Give details.

1895 we had no vegetables but lambs quarter greens
grown on a now abandoned farm ½ mile away
for a while rabbit meat, frozen wheat bread,
later found a meadow where we lot butter out of milk
some potatoes grown in Qu'Appelle valley.
20. Mention any outstanding differences in the preparation of meals in the earliest days as compared with today.

Flour was very poor and flour certainly was no variety & vegatables or fruit 1894-1896.

21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In 1943 we used lots of canned tomatoes but by 1945 times were better and we could buy tomatoes and would buy honey hot orange marmalade and maple syrup, we had by 600 lbs from east and maple syrup we had been used to before we left east.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

White sugar came in 100 lb bags, same sugar at about $3.00 per lb about 1903 or 1904, we did type the sugar in sugar sacks to come could buy a new cotton grain bag & have sugar filled in it.
21. When did you begin to rely on purchased foods and prepared foods instead of homegrown and home prepared foods? (Give as many details and dates as possible).

In 1943 we used lots of canned tomatoes, but by last fall we were better off and could buy some tomatoes.

For orange marmalade, and would buy honey by bulk tons from east, and maple syrup, we had been used to before we left east.

22. Please add other details from your early experiences of buying groceries and securing foods in other ways during pioneer days in Western Canada. Include items not mentioned above, quality, methods of merchandising, prices, problems of storage, shortages and other details. (Use back of page if more space is needed).

White sugar came in 100 lb. bags, later sugar at about $5.00 per lb. about 1903-1904, we did buy the sugar at the store filled in it.

Brown sugar was never used in it.
